Posts.EditableText: If I create a game, using the Website. How do I download the game to my own PC ?
Posts.HTML: If I create a game, using the Website. How do I download the game to my own PC ?

Posts.EditableText: I have been working on a game for over a year (using the online version of the editor) and I still cannot download it from the internet ! I am also having absolutely zero results "publishing it"!!
Posts.HTML: I have been working on a game for over a year (using the online version of the editor) and I still cannot download it from the internet ! I am also having absolutely zero results "publishing it"!!

Posts.EditableText: If you want a copy of the .aslx file so that you can continue working on your game using the desktop Quest, click on "Create" at the top of the site and look down your list of games. They should have a "Download" button. If you want to download the published .quest file ready to play, you'll need to publish the game first (you can do this without making it listed on the website if you want) and then click on "View/edit game listing" and download it from there. (the only downside to publishing a game is that you can no longer delete it)
Posts.HTML:
If you want a copy of the .aslx file so that you can continue working on your game using the desktop Quest, click on "Create" at the top of the site and look down your list of games. They should have a "Download" button.

If you want to download the published .quest file ready to play, you'll need to publish the game first (you can do this without making it listed on the website if you want) and then click on "View/edit game listing" and download it from there.

(the only downside to publishing a game is that you can no longer delete it)

Posts.EditableText: Wow, I’ve been looking for the same information; thanks for helping. I’m a hardcore gamer, and for me, it is really important to have a high-resolution monitor. I bought a new monitor two weeks ago, and it said that it was 4k, but I’m really Incredulous when it comes to stuff like that. It may say whatever it wants on the cover, but I still won’t trust it. Eventually, I looked for some answers on the internet, and I found a website https://digitalmasta.com/can-my-computer-run-4k/ that had all the information I was looking for. I read an article about computer resolutions and how to understand its 4k. My monitor ended up being 4k.
